nova/compute/api.py.message: Are you planning to add a microversion for this, once it's possible for this to be true? Right now, it's synchronous until the host is verified it sounds like, so making it async in some situations would be a bit of a change in behavior. Also, it looks like this would make any user who can do cross-cell migrations have async resizes always, which isn't necessarily a thing they would know about. Wouldn't it be confusing to be developing an app with your credentials, always get a 202 and instant return, then deploy that app with some service credentials only to find that it is getting 200s and blocking calls?

> Are you planning to add a microversion for this, once it's possible for this to be true?

No, I'm not planning on that.

It's a 202 either way so the user either gets a quickish response (same cell resize assuming scheduling doesn't take a noticeable amount of time) or a quick response (cross-cell resize), but they don't know either way so I don't see the reason for a microversion.

I called this out specifically in the spec and there appeared to not be issues with it, but maybe the dots weren't connecting at that time (#2 here):

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/cross-cell-resize.html#api

I don't really want to go the way of the 2.34 microversion which made live migration a cast from the API because as noted, users shouldn't have to know if they are resizing across cells and opt into it - operators want to enable it to migrate users without their knowledge really to drain old cells.

> It is probably an unfortunate loss of data to always make this a cast, but I think the consistency argument is a win over whatever you might glean from the synchronous call.

What loss of data? Do you just mean immediate failures like NoValidHost during scheduling? The user still gets that stuff via instance actions if the operation fails.

The tl;dr user experience on this is:

1. make the request,
2. get a 202,
3. poll until the server status is VERIFY_RESIZE or timeout,
4. if timeout, check instance actions

That doesn't change whether we cast or call here. The only difference is what might fail in between and come back out of the API, but that's not really a contractual thing people should be building apps around, right? That's why we have an instance actions API for tracking the progress of an operation.

Okay, since this doesn't enable anything, if you're going to switch it to always cast and update the error handling, I'll +W this and you can queue up that change. It only needs to come before the switch to turn this on, but ideally earlier for context.

I imagine gibi will be okay with that change, but if not, we can argue it out on that patch at that time.

> Okay, I thought based on the comment that it would be a 200 now,
 > and maybe assumed that you'd be in verify state after that if
 > everything went well.

Ack. FWIW, the comment doesn't mention the response code but the commit message does. Since the thing that controls the response code is separate from this code I didn't mention it in the comment here.

 > > I don't really want to go the way of the 2.34 microversion which
 > > made live migration a cast from the API because as noted, users
 > > shouldn't have to know if they are resizing across cells and opt
 > > into it - operators want to enable it to migrate users without
 > > their knowledge really to drain old cells.
 > 
 > Right, as mentioned, I don't want a microversion for this because
 > it doesn't seem like something the user should opt-in to. What I do
 > want is consistency. If it's 202 right now, and the user shouldn't
 > be depending on the timing of the response to know if scheduling
 > worked or not, why can't we just always make this a cast so that
 > we're behaving the same for both cross- and same-cell migrations?

We can make it a cast, that's fine with me. It wasn't until I started work on this feature that I even realized same-cell resize was a synchronous call all the way through to the prep_resize cast to the first selected dest compute. That was a surprise to me since most API operations should cast to conductor/compute so you get a quick response.
If I make it a cast in all cases:

1. There is likely error handling in the route handler code that could go away, like NoValidHost - I don't want to clean that up here in this patch so I'm assuming people would be fine with doing that cleanup either in a follow up or creating a separate patch before this one that makes all resizes an async cast from API to conductor.
2. Is a release note necessary for the behavior change in the same-cell resize case?

 > > The tl;dr user experience on this is:
 > >
 > > 1. make the request,
 > > 2. get a 202,
 > > 3. poll until the server status is VERIFY_RESIZE or timeout,
 > > 4. if timeout, check instance actions
 > >
 > > That doesn't change whether we cast or call here. The only
 > > difference is what might fail in between and come back out of the
 > > API, but that's not really a contractual thing people should be
 > > building apps around, right? That's why we have an instance
 > actions
 > > API for tracking the progress of an operation.
 > 
 > Well, I dunno if they do or not. What happens if we get a
 > NoValidHost in the synchronous call? Do we still return 202 or some
 > 4xx?

The user gets a 400 in that case:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/17b5a1ab85c358a1096788371849f0cccfe84972/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L978

 > If the former, then cool, and we should be able to make them
 > both cast and unify the behavior. If the latter, then this is
 > indeed a change in behavior for cross-cell, in which case the
 > behavior (defined or determined) will be different depending on the
 > policy. Regardless of the failure case, I think it's legit to move
 > them both to cast at this point, since the current 202 should mean
 > you have to poll for status anyway and to avoid people building
 > future reliance on the scheduling being part of the return status
 > right?

Again I'm OK with changing to a cast in all cases, but figured others wouldn't be so that's why I made this conditional.

It would be nice if at least gibi, who is +2 on this right now, is also OK with making this a cast in all cases so I don't have to flip flop on this later when I separate out that change and rebase the entire stack.

> Okay, since this doesn't enable anything, if you're going to switch
 > it to always cast and update the error handling, I'll +W this and
 > you can queue up that change. It only needs to come before the
 > switch to turn this on, but ideally earlier for context.
 > 
 > I imagine gibi will be okay with that change, but if not, we can
 > argue it out on that patch at that time.

Done: https://review.opendev.org/693937

Yeah, I'd prefer consistency as the user doesn't know if they're allowed to do cross-cell, whether or not they're going to get one, or even if the cloud they're on *has* multiple cells. It is probably an unfortunate loss of data to always make this a cast, but I think the consistency argument is a win over whatever you might glean from the synchronous call.

I'm still not sure on the microversion part. Obviously we *can* make cross-cell migration a microversion and refuse to do it for older ones (and thus keep this synchronous in those cases). However, i thought that we were never supposed to add microversions for things the user wouldn't opt-in to? Like, users won't opt-in to "a better error message" or "a response body with more consistent capital letters." Since they don't know about cells, whether or not they have that permission, etc, why would the user choose to use microversion 2.X in this case? Obviously if 2.Y has some feature they want then they will opt-in to it over time, but...

Anyway, the microversion part is something we need to decide and do, but my concern is the user-invisible inconsistent result and behavior.

This is indeed a bit weird for the reasons Dan states.

If at time A user X and Y would both get the same response when doing this operation, and then at B they _might_ a get different response because of the addition of this code and a change in policy, and the response is not a 403 but some form of success (i.e., 2xx) then a microversion is warranted because code expectations are violated.

That's all further complicated by the fact that there are plenty of things happening under the covers here that the API user isn't necessarily going to be aware of (cells, policies, whatevers).

Is there a way to make it always a cast from microversion X onwards? For sake of consistency?

Also note that if we make this a cast in all cases then I will also be reverting this change we just recently merged:

I9115ef6df59844cd6e702f19ba38ffbf9f8b35d3

Not a big deal to me, just FYI.

> Also note that if we make this a cast in all cases then I will also
 > be reverting this change we just recently merged:
 > 
 > I9115ef6df59844cd6e702f19ba38ffbf9f8b35d3
 > 
 > Not a big deal to me, just FYI.

Well, maybe not. migrate_server is still called from the compute during a reschedule within a same-cell resize so I think I might want to leave that as a synchronous call still since otherwise it's a bigger change to deal with in the prep_resize reschedule code. So the change would just be API -> (super) conductor = RPC cast, leave compute -> (cell) conductor = RPC call.

> It's a 202 either way so the user either gets a quickish response
 > (same cell resize assuming scheduling doesn't take a noticeable
 > amount of time) or a quick response (cross-cell resize), but they
 > don't know either way so I don't see the reason for a microversion.

Okay, I thought based on the comment that it would be a 200 now, and maybe assumed that you'd be in verify state after that if everything went well.

 > I called this out specifically in the spec and there appeared to
 > not be issues with it, but maybe the dots weren't connecting at
 > that time (#2 here):

Yeah, forgive me for not being able to get this all in my head ahead of time.

 > I don't really want to go the way of the 2.34 microversion which
 > made live migration a cast from the API because as noted, users
 > shouldn't have to know if they are resizing across cells and opt
 > into it - operators want to enable it to migrate users without
 > their knowledge really to drain old cells.

Right, as mentioned, I don't want a microversion for this because it doesn't seem like something the user should opt-in to. What I do want is consistency. If it's 202 right now, and the user shouldn't be depending on the timing of the response to know if scheduling worked or not, why can't we just always make this a cast so that we're behaving the same for both cross- and same-cell migrations?

 > What loss of data? Do you just mean immediate failures like
 > NoValidHost during scheduling? The user still gets that stuff via
 > instance actions if the operation fails.

Yes, that's what I meant, but see above.

 > The tl;dr user experience on this is:
 > 
 > 1. make the request,
 > 2. get a 202,
 > 3. poll until the server status is VERIFY_RESIZE or timeout,
 > 4. if timeout, check instance actions
 > 
 > That doesn't change whether we cast or call here. The only
 > difference is what might fail in between and come back out of the
 > API, but that's not really a contractual thing people should be
 > building apps around, right? That's why we have an instance actions
 > API for tracking the progress of an operation.

Well, I dunno if they do or not. What happens if we get a NoValidHost in the synchronous call? Do we still return 202 or some 4xx? If the former, then cool, and we should be able to make them both cast and unify the behavior. If the latter, then this is indeed a change in behavior for cross-cell, in which case the behavior (defined or determined) will be different depending on the policy. Regardless of the failure case, I think it's legit to move them both to cast at this point, since the current 202 should mean you have to poll for status anyway and to avoid people building future reliance on the scheduling being part of the return status right?

nova/conductor/rpcapi.py.message: There is a list of expected exceptions decorated on the migrate_server function of the conductor.manager. Do I understand correctly that with call() those exceptions went back to the API user, but with the new cast() path, those will be dropped? By reading the doc of that decorator I'm not even sure that the these exception will be logged when they bubble up to the top of the RPC method.

Thanks. 

So there is a catch-all in the conductor manager that leads to a warning log (and to error state and notification sending). I rest my case.

> There is a list of expected exceptions decorated on the
 > migrate_server function of the conductor.manager. Do I understand
 > correctly that with call() those exceptions went back to the API
 > user, but with the new cast() path, those will be dropped?

Correct. With the call they'd be handled in the wsgi controller code:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ee6b69cadc75219aa53bdb91bb71a8b0cedd215b/nova/api/openstack/compute/migrate_server.py#L71

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ee6b69cadc75219aa53bdb91bb71a8b0cedd215b/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L951

 By
 > reading the doc of that decorator I'm not even sure that the these
 > exception will be logged when they bubble up to the top of the RPC
 > method.

I think if you bubble an exception up to the expected_exceptions decorator it only gets logged (as an exception) if it's not expected:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/40c25c2bde6d2f5a756e7169060b7ce389caf174/oslo_messaging/rpc/server.py#L169

Otherwise it's logged at debug.

Note that there is error handling here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ee6b69cadc75219aa53bdb91bb71a8b0cedd215b/nova/conductor/manager.py#L332

And we'll log the error (and send a notification and record a fault) here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ee6b69cadc75219aa53bdb91bb71a8b0cedd215b/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L723

keystone/common/sql/contract_repo/versio.message:
Question: Do we really need this as domain.id isn't referenced to project.id foreign key[1] ?

[1 https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py#L39]

You're conflating the sqlalchemy model with the actual table. If you go to your devstack and do 'show create table `user`' on the keystone database in mysql you will see the foreign key exists.

These schema migrations are imperative instructions that act on the database itself to bring it from one state to another. The sqlalchemy model is a declarative description of what the table is supposed to look like and acts as an interface between the database and the calling code.

deploy-guide/source/features/distributed.message:
If we want to turn this into an include list instead of adding a Ceph exclude, then I found two options which work for launching an instance:

1. Python
import yaml
keys = ['KeystoneCredential0', 'KeystoneCredential1', 'KeystoneFernetKey0', 'KeystoneFernetKey1', 'KeystoneFernetKeys', 'RabbitCookie', 'RabbitPassword', 'NovaPassword', 'NovajoinPassword', 'MysqlClustercheckPassword', 'MysqlRootPassword', 'NeutronMetadataProxySharedSecret', 'NeutronPassword', 'CinderPassword', 'RedisPassword']
data=yaml.safe_load(open('plan-environment.yaml').read())
passwords = { key: data['passwords'][key] for key in keys }
print(yaml.dump(dict(parameter_defaults=passwords)))

2. Shell
python3 -c "import yaml; data=yaml.safe_load(open('plan-environment.yaml').read()); print(yaml.dump(dict(parameter_defaults=data['passwords'])))" > all_passwords.yaml
cat all_passwords.yaml | egrep -i "parameter|rabbit|mysql|keystone|nova|neutron" > passwords.yaml
rm all_passwords.yaml

If we want an include list, I think #2 is shorter than expanding our python one-liner to have the long keys list from #1. Both will need variations so that Cinder/Glance work, but I think both of these make the doc more complicated.

Maybe we should just exclude Ceph to fix the duplicate password issue quickly and plan for https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1850636 to provide the easier fix while adding a warning about only not including all passwords for power users who choose to build an include/exclude list themselves.

I'll try that in a follow up PS.

Removing Ceph passwords makes sense when a new cluster is deployed at the Edge. However, this doc doesn't say much about persistent storage (or glance image handling) at the edge. I'm not sure what to recommend, but unilaterally removing Ceph passwords may be overreaching.

It seems to be more than the rabbitmq password. 

With just rabbit it times out waiting for the nova-compute service to register during deployment on step 4:

          "keystoneauth1.exceptions.http.Unauthorized: The request you have made requires authentication. (HTTP 401) (Request-ID: req-4f99accb-fa9e-46a9-9232-e8a577ab6f3d)",
          "ERROR:nova_wait_for_compute_service:Error while waiting for nova-compute service to register",

More details in:

(undercloud) [stack@undercloud edge0]$ cat ansible-errors.json | jq . | tail -300 | curl -F 'f:1=<-' ix.io 
http://ix.io/20lt
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud edge0]$

I think we had a disucssion a while back about nova computes needing to connect to MySQL too. 

I tried a few combinations and I was unable to launch an instance unless I did the following after the python one-liner produced extracted_passwords.yaml

cat extracted_passwords.yaml | egrep -i "parameter|rabbit|mysql|keystone|nova|neutron" > passwords.yaml

I needed the neutron passwords or I hit this: http://ix.io/20qF

I did more experimentation and I'm having an issue getting Cinder and the early Glance cache options working without additional passwords.
Perhaps wrap this in a command so we can filter it correctly for the user. I've never liked the raw python above anyway

I agree about adding a command to take care of this for the user. That's tracked in:

 https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1850636

For now though I think we should at least get the Ceph example in this document working so all the Ceph clusters are not deployed with the same password.

> Removing Ceph passwords makes sense when a new cluster is deployed
 > at the Edge. However, this doc doesn't say much about persistent
 > storage (or glance image handling) at the edge. I'm not sure what
 > to recommend, but unilaterally removing Ceph passwords may be
 > overreaching.

Because this document covers Ceph (line 537) I think it's worse to have repeated FSIDs and passwords than unilaterally remove Ceph passwords. I don't think we should keep them just in case we need them later. I think waiting for it to cover the other storage stuff would take too long (too much work for this small patch to prevent people from getting repeat passwrods). We are working on that but I don't think we should wait for it to delay this patch. I think we should exclude Ceph from the extraction so the Ceph example works and then in a subsequent patch add more storage items.

maybe we should be more specific about what passwords actually do need to be reused.

I guess it may just be the rabbitmq password.
Ceph is covered here and shouldn't be removed because it works aside from making each ceph cluster have the same FSID and passwords which this patch is fixing.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
There are much more use cases:
1. VM is under the dvr router, but the compute host's L3 agent mode is dvr_no_external, then in snat node L3 agent (dvr_snat), the floating IPs will be set in the snat-namespace. The device is also qg- interface.
2. Mixed compute node and snat node, the agent mode will be dvr_snat. Then the qrouter-namespace and rfp-device will be used for floating IPs for this host. Such mixed deployment is mostly used in upstream CI.

These patch sets handle these scenario well?
This is the original RFE: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1667877

Yes, you are going to fix the bug of dvr metering, so it is DVR. : )

For dvr_no_external node, qrouter-namespace will not have that rfp-device.

One more question, for east-west traffic of internal IPs only (we can create metering rule for fixed IPs, right?), this will handle that properly since the traffic will be routed locally in compute node, the traffic direction could be a problem? This could be a very complicated case...

The metering agent doesn't handle east-west traffic. I'm only trying to fix the metering agent for DVR routers, not to enhance its functionality.

About dvr_no_external, can you please point me to some documentation that explains all the agent modes and how they route traffic?

The driver checks the router type (distributed or centralized) and the available iptables namespaces (qrouter and snat) to determine on what interfaces to apply metering rules on. Here is a pseudocode:

```
if the qrouter- namespace is available:
  if router is distributed:
    apply metering rules on the rfp- device from the qrouter- namespace
  else:
    apply metering rules on the qg- device from the qrouter- namespace

if the snat- namespace is available:
  apply metering rules on the qg- device from the snat- namespace
```

For the use cases you described:
1. On the snat node: the router is distributed, the snat- namespace is available, so the qg- device on the snat- namespace will be metered. On the compute host the rfp- device on the qrouter- namespace will also be metered, but I don't think any traffic flows through it. Please correct me if I'm wrong.
2. I assume you're talking about a distributed router, in which case the rfp- device from the qrouter- namespace will be metered.

In conclusion, I believe my patches handle these scenarios properly.

So if east-west is not your case, but for floating IP and gateway IP only, then I have an alternative here, it does not require metering agent, but gives you same functionality with a new L3 agent extension only:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658511/

Bence, thank you for the detailed explanation.

I agree with your findings and would start with removing the decorator from OVSNeutronAgent and applying it only to methods triggered by RPC. This will avoid call to profiler.stop() which now happens on return from process_port_info()

Then the question is the span lifetime - the span starts once trace context is read from OVS port, but when can it be considered as finished? Does it live within one iteration of rpc_loop() or longer?

> I agree with your findings and would start with removing the
 > decorator from OVSNeutronAgent and applying it only to methods
 > triggered by RPC. This will avoid call to profiler.stop() which now
 > happens on return from process_port_info()

I started doing this so we'll never have unmatched profiler.stop()s. I had to realize that in neutron-ovs-agent the trace_info is lost from the context before we call profiler.init() in deserialize_context(). I'm now debugging why that happens.

 > Then the question is the span lifetime - the span starts once trace
 > context is read from OVS port, but when can it be considered as
 > finished? Does it live within one iteration of rpc_loop() or
 > longer?

I'd like to consider the end of the span when neutron-ovs-agent sends the update_device_list rpc to neutron-server setting the port status to some final status like ACTIVE. I think the reinit() method in my current osprofiler change is seriously ugly - I'd like to get rid of it somehow. One idea I have (at least as a first step) is to only pass the trace_info through neutron-ovs-agent and do not call profiler.init() from ovs-agent. Still we would have trace points from nova/os-vif (before ovs-agent) and neutron-server (after ovs-agent). So we could tell the total time spent in ovs-agent. But this way we could avoid the need for reinit() or deinit() in osprofiler. But I'll have to experiment with this.

In short: _process_port is triggered by polling of ovsdb.

The background of this WIP change may not come through properly from these patches so let me explain:

When we looked into osprofiler reports of a full VM boot (with vNICs) we realized there are no trace points after the vif plug. However many things happen after the vif plug: most importantly neutron-agent wires the port, then it sends an rpc back to neutron-server to update the port status, then neutron-server calls back to nova to resume the VM boot. And we'd like to profile all this.

As I'm sure you know the original integration work of osprofiler added the trace info to all the usual communication channels like HTTP calls and RPC messages to trigger tracing in other components. But vif plugging is non-standard unfortunately. Usually what happens is the following: nova (through os-vif) plugs an interface into the softswitch and a neutron agent polls on the softswitch configuration and realizes there's a new interface. This is a communication channel where the trace info is not passed at the moment, therefore the trace ends in nova/os-vif.

In addition to this the ovs-agent architecture is a spaghetti, so we're trying to find the least hacky way to enable tracing after the vif plug.

As you can see in line 100 the OVSNeutronAgent class is currenty decorated to be traced. The "rpc" string there is quite misleading. Many of the methods of this class are not remote methods. But even the methods called remotely are not doing any real work - they only update global state variables in ovs-agent, so the next loop can pick up the work to do. The single most important operation of ovs-agent (i.e. the vif plug) is not triggered by rpc.

I'm not sure if we should keep the decorator on OVSNeutronAgent. But when it's there combined with the profiler.init() in process_ports_events() we are going to see profiler.stop()s without the corresponding profiler.start()s. Because we can only init() the profiler in the middle of the decorated process_ports_events() method. Maybe we should delete the decorator and hand pick code locations for profiler.start/stops so we never have unmatched stop()s.

The ovs-agent loop itself interleaves work that could belong to many trace requests. Even the rpc message back to neutron is a batched message so it could be part of many traces at once while the rpc message format currently allows only a single trace info.

I'm not sure how much useful profiling information we can get out of ovs-agent - because even the best profiling here will ultimately just measure the length of the rpc_loop in ovs-agent. But I would definitely want to pass the trace info back to neutron-server so we can see the overall time spent in ovs-agent and follow the trace from there.

We uploaded these changes hoping that people have ideas how to make all this less hacky while still providing useful tracing data.

mistral/engine/tasks.py.message: I think adding imports inside a function is a bad practice. Probably we can move it to the other imports at the top?
is there some reason why this cannot be moved to the file header?

Cyclic dependency I guess. I also hate such places but sometimes it's easier to so rather than change the architecture.

Overall, this code snippet is a "bad smell" to me because at this level Task object shouldn't know anything about a specific workflow type (direct, reverse etc.) about about any specific language constructions like "join". That's why at this level we use terms like "defer" and "deferred". That tells that a task execution may be deferred for some time due to some unsatisfied conditions. So please consider a more abstract approach. May be you can delegate something to the workflow controller. I don't say "no" strictly. Just please think more about it and let's discuss.

I think the restricting log message is useful and clear and aligned with what was logged before, since we know in that case we're not going to another cell. The "preferring cell" one is more dubious since by default the CrossCellWeigher will prefer the same source cell but could be configured to prefer other cells if you're trying to drain a given cell via aggregates. So maybe I'll changing "Preferring" to "Allowing cross-cell move".

So if I remove the comments/logic from here, does it make more sense if I move the "if self.request_spec.requested_destination.allow_cross_cell_move" condition above into the if block where the request_spec already has a requested_destination set by the API? In that case either an admin is cold migrating to a specific host and/or we're allowing a cross-cell resize.

Either the old debug log or new log message with the 'restricting to cell' wording would be an either else case, i.e. there is a requested_destination already but allow_cross_cell_move is false, or there was no requested_destination set at all yet (else block above). I think I probably did the logic down below so I didn't have to duplicate the log message for those 2 else cases above.

I think you could nuke the log message entirely, or put it over in host manager, which actually decides what to do with this. However, moving/changing the comment as I (and you) described would make this more clearly just a hint to the log reader.

I think best way to parse RC files is calling bash and printout result. For example you could  do something like below

 bash -c "source '{{ rc_file }}'; env" | grep '^OS_' | xargs echo

The resulting output could be put in a ansible variable. Esample:

 OS_PROJECT_NAME=admin OS_PASSWORD=RNMFKzewK4yn9TTzphRhmeJ29 OS_AUTH_URL=http://10.0.0.109:5000/v2.0 OS_USERNAME=admin OS_TENANT_NAME=admin OS_NO_CACHE=True OS_CLOUDNAME=overcloud

Then it could be used in bash to be prepended to tobiko-keystone-credentials command to have them translated by tobiko.

 {{ tobiko_rc_vars }} tobiko-keystone-credentials

Above comand would generate a yaml dictionary easy to be parsed by ansible and to be used later to write tobiko.conf file.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This failed because castellan was trying to create a trust for a different user or?

no, this is when the incoming token is already created from trust (like e.g. Heat ones for deferred auth when autoscaling).
Instead of just re-using the token, Castellan tries to create a new token from existing one, and this is forbidden for trust-generated tokens in Keystone.

neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/.message: I still have a question about this "autoincrement" parameter. The binding_index field will link a network with several agents. But this value should start, for each network, from 1.  Doing this, we'll have something like a "id" parameter with autoincrement. That information is irrevelant for the "networkdhcpagentbindings" register because we don't need an "id" field.

Let me just delete it since "SQLite does not support autoincrement for composite primary keys" anyway. That would mean that we tolerate unique constraint violation when auto-scheduling networks during rolling upgrade (when some non-upgraded servers are running against upgraded DB)

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/ingress/ingr.message: Does this mean that all routes will be exposed as https?

@Toni,

No.

1. Routes will be exposed as http or https according to ocp-route spec.

2. We create here two (HTTP,HTTPS) listeners, the route-handler should bind the L7policy to the right listener based on ocp-route spec.
